comments.commentBody: Jim, you have your priorities and we have ours. Let's face it, this isn't an issue for you because you are not the one having to come out of closet, get bullied, get ridiculed, get discriminated against or even get killed for simply being ourselves. Our lives do matter and until we get the same rights and the protection that you seem so quick to dismiss, we will continue to do what we can to be heard. you will not stop hearing from us.
Restoring the right to vote to American citizens who have paid their dues will encourage them to commit another crime?!! Good Lord, now I've heard everything.
Sounds like we need to revamp our for-profit prison system and spend more money on rehabilitation.
And if we ban the box, I bet those rates will drop even more too.
Ha! Jim Crow laws were enacted by Southern Democrats.

My guess is that Philip kills Martha. He has her gun, and we all know that if there's a gun in act one, it will be fired in act three. Philip will meet up with Martha, realize that she's beyond saving, and tragically shoot her when her back is turned. My prediction, at least.
you could be right about hank and nacho...in BB, in the desert scene he says "it wasn't me,it was Ignacio"...they already said that was Nacho....I think he plays diff sides.

Not talking about things doesn't make them go away. Ditto pretending everything is fine when it isn't. Shakespeare seems to me the absolutely perfect way to get teens to reflect, consider, and analyze the situation at their school. The play is removed enough to feel safe, but real enough to matter.

There are some valuable lessons in Romeo and Juliet. So I don't think we should censor it out of classrooms. Looking at drama through different character's perspectives is more of an exercise in empathy, not an encouragement in rebellion.

Also, do you know who the only youth that lives in the end of R&J is? It's Benvolio! The character who is, in today's language, the most level-headed. He tries to talk Romeo out of falling so drastically in-love. But once we let our passions (in a Stoic sense) take over...

As far as I know, Romeo and Juliet has been assigned reading for students for at least 30 years.  Sorry, but you can't make things go away by not addressing them.  One of my bosses committed suicide during the economic downturn, I still had to be at work the day after, there's no escaping the facts of life.

Why is my 14 year old daughter currently studying the suicides of Romeo and Juliet at school this week. Can't we find a different Shakespeare story given everything going on. A student took his life a couple months ago in her school and it was surprising to learn today their assignment was to argue/debate both sides (both sides?) of Romeo's situation.

" What is the point of keeping people alive if they don't want to be around themselves anymore?"

" ...they embraced death as a solution to exit life when it could not have been lived in a dignified way anymore."

How about fixing things so that those people actually WANT to be around more and CAN live in a dignified way??

Sounds to me like a MUCH BETTER solution than just more and more people just killing themselves.

It worries me when someone does not think of the OBVIOUS Solutions...

I agree that it's not as bad in most of Europe, but it's also not as good as it used to be.  The safety nets are fraying here as well.  Germany is still rich in comparison to Greece, but senior citizen poverty is a growing concern.

Very well said. And sadly, the answer to your question of "how long will we tolerate?" this state of affairs has no answer, because "we" (meaning the vast majority of us reading and commenting here) have no choice but to tolerate it. The fix is in, and on a scale few of us ever imagined possible. A massive confluence of industrial/organizational psychology tricks, technology, advertising, politics, greed and hyper-concentrated wealth has created an America where our only real choice remaining is to tolerate this sorry mode of living, or make an early exit and be added to the number of those counted among these alarming statistics.

Why are more people here killing themselves? Very likely because they have the bad luck to live in a country that views people as basically disposable, less important than money or property, and has allowed policies that reward employers for working those they hire 24/7/365 if possible (That 'exempt employees' yearly salary system is one of the worst abuses you can imagine.) Not only that, just consider what it takes to even have a shot at getting a job, especially in any place that's considered a 'trendy' or 'hip' youth magnet - a conforming extrovert's social media profile and even a gym-toned physique, as well as the ability to psych out those mumbo-jumbo online 'personality' tests so loved by so many bosses these days. To that, add the relentless propaganda barrage that keeps telling us that there is basically no such thing as a stable career and that we'll all have to spend our lives competing and conforming to avoid ending up starving amongst the homeless. Frankly, the current situation in America is making George Orwell look like an OPTIMIST. It's also an insane recipe for social discord. At least in the Euro Zone, where wage-hours laws eliminate the 'exempt' loophole and such matters as social media and even your charge card purchases are off-limits to employers, they still hire mere human beings and don't let their unemployed citizens starve in the streets. So how long will we tolerate what's basically become a heartless society that outdoes the world of Dickens?

That's it.

Well Said.

But I worry if Well Heard?

Socialism?

That's really funny for you to say that...

Especially when Suicide is all about "Isolationism" of Spirit, Mind and Hope.

...of the Individual.

Until we start seeing Group Suicides and Community Kill Offs I think we can safely say that Socialism is not the cause.
Sad that you have to qualify your astute observation as sarcasm. Spot on, bravo.
I hope you voted for Sanders, because it is sad to see how many people don't see the connection.

Then DO IT!

I haven't seen Americans Unite together under a Common Cause nor do so for the Common Good for ages.Because you are too busy hating each other and fearing each other and have been in continual conflict with each other most of your history.

Now that the pie is getting even smaller as the demands of the Tiny Few get ever Taller...

Most of you just pick up speed as more from further, Faller.
I hope you are blogging because this was amazing and America needs your perspective.
very eloquent and moving. I hope you find your peace

You're absolutely right, Socrates.

I'm about to become a part of these statistics, not because I want to die, but because I have no other choice.

As a chronically ill middle aged woman who can no longer work, has no family and no friends who are in any position to take on the burden of my care.

A generation ago, I'd have reached a place in my field which might have made working still possible and afforded me a way to earn enough to hang on. But over the last couple of decades worker protections and pay have eroded in my area of expertise.

I wish I could stick around, I want to live even if I am in physical pain, but I don't want to be sick and homeless. So in a few months I will take a one way flight to Switzerland as a suicide tourist. It isn't what I really want, it's simply the best of many bad options.

Yeah you're absolutely right, Melo is exactly what they Knicks need, no heart volume shooter. Let's stay the course and maybe we'll make the playoffs. By the way, how did Calderon work out? Lin was good for the Knicks and he brought new people and positive coverage.

And too much DEMOCRAT Complicity. Don't think they should not get the blame as well.

It takes TWO to do a Tango that destroys so much and so many so completely....

Yeah if I'm ever forced to be addicted to what is essentially heroin (I'm assuming you are on a bunch of opiates) by doctors, I don't think I would allow it. I used to be an oxycontin addict, and when I quit I met sooooo many seniors who were addicted to pain medicine until they died. They would be in a fog, not really living life, just waiting for the end to come. I'd rather live my life as healthy and addiction-free as I can, and if the pain ever becomes too much, I think I'd probably end it. Doctors want to think they can give us options to live forever, but in reality we cannot. Opiates are the worst medicine on planet earth. Try CBD, all natural and very effective for chronic pain while not being addictive and evil :-)

I am very old.  I have many pain-related problems.  About my "Polypharmacy":  GO AWAY!!!!   I need all the help I can get.  Leave me alone.  And my doctors.  And my pharmacists.  Unfortunately, I must declare great problems for YOUR physical future:  LIFE WILL HURT!  Like Hell!  Now, go away and leave my pills alone.  And wait for the pain.......IT IS COMING!

Several years ago on an 'older folks' tour (everyone over 55) one of the participants said jokingly, "Everyone bring your bag of pills to breakfast tomorrow morning;  whoever has the most wins." No one did, but it would have been interesting.

It's a team game.

That was a disappointing effort by everybody.

The focus on Lundqvist is beside the point.
And, do not forget:  that "FLAG" is just as dangerous if not more so than the original problem.  Just you wait, Henry Higgins!
Yes!  Been thru that!  Finally ended up with each of us counting and directing and ensuring consumption of all those little pills we need.  So far it is working.....I think....
